infodynamics.measures.continuous.gaussian
Class ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian

java.lang.Object
  infodynamics.measures.continuous.ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
      infodynamics.measures.continuous.gaussian.ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian
All Implemented Interfaces:
ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, AnalyticNullDistributionComputer, java.lang.Cloneable
public class ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian
extends ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon
implements ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate, AnalyticNullDistributionComputer, java.lang.Cloneable

Computes the differential conditional mutual information of two given multivariate sets of observations, assuming that the probability distribution function for these observations is a multivariate Gaussian distribution.

Usage:

  1. Construct #ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateLinearGaussian()
  2. #initialise(int, int)
  3. Set properties using setProperty(String, String)
  4. Provide the observations to the calculator using: #setObservations(double[][], double[][]), or setCovariance(double[][]), or a sequence of: ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon.startAddObservations(), multiple calls to either #addObservations(double[][], double[][]) or #addObservations(double[][], double[][], int, int), and then finaliseAddObservations().
  5. Compute the required information-theoretic results, primarily: computeAverageLocalOfObservations() to return the average differential entropy based on either the set variance or the variance of the supplied observations; or other calls to compute local values or statistical significance.

Author:
Joseph Lizier joseph.lizier_at_gmail.com
See Also:
Differential entropy for Gaussian random variables at Mathworld, Differential entropy for Gaussian random variables at Wikipedia, Multivariate normal distribution on Wikipedia

Field Detail

L

protected double[][] L
Cached Cholesky decomposition of the covariance matrix of the most recently supplied observations. Is a matrix [C_11, C_12, C_1c; C_21, C_22, C_2c; C_c1, C_c2, C_cc], where C_xy represents the covariance matrix of variable x to variable y where x,y are either variable 1, 2 or the conditional. The covariance matrix is symmetric, and should be positive definite (otherwise we have linealy dependent variables).

L_1c

protected double[][] L_1c
Cached Cholesky decomposition of the (var1, conditional) covariance matrix

L_2c

protected double[][] L_2c
Cached Cholesky decomposition of the (var2, conditional) covariance matrix

L_cc

Cached Cholesky decomposition of the conditional covariance matrix

setCovariance

public void setCovariance(double[][] covariance)
                   throws java.lang.Exception

Set the covariance of the distribution for which we will compute the conditional mutual information.

Note that without setting any observations, you cannot later call computeLocalOfPreviousObservations(), and without providing the means of the variables, you cannot later call #computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][], double[][]).

Parameters:
covariance - covariance matrix of var1, var2, conditional variables, considered together.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - for covariance matrix not matching the expected dimensions, being non-square, asymmetric or non-positive definite

protected void setCovariance(double[][] covariance,
                             boolean determinedFromObservations)
                      throws java.lang.Exception

Set the covariance of the distribution for which we will compute the conditional mutual information.

Note that without setting any observations, you cannot later call computeLocalOfPreviousObservations(), and without providing the means of the variables, you cannot later call #computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][], double[][]).

Parameters:
covariance - covariance matrix of var1, var2 and the conditional variables, considered together.
determinedFromObservations - whether the covariance matrix was determined internally from observations or not
Throws:
java.lang.Exception - for covariance matrix not matching the expected dimensions, being non-square, asymmetric or non-positive definite

computeAverageLocalOfObservations

public double computeAverageLocalOfObservations()
                                         throws java.lang.Exception

The joint differential entropy for a multivariate Gaussian-distribution of dimension n with covariance matrix C is -0.5*\log_e{(2*pi*e)^n*|det(C)|}, where det() is the matrix determinant of C.

Here we compute the conditional mutual information from the joint entropies of all variables (H_12c), variable 1 and conditional (H_1c), variable 2 and conditional (H_2c) and conditional (H_c), giving MI = H_1c + H_2c - H_c - H_12c. We assume that the recorded estimation of the covariance is correct (i.e. we will not make a bias correction for limited observations here).

Specified by:
computeAverageLocalOfObservations in interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate
Returns:
the mutual information of the previously provided observations or from the supplied covariance matrix, in nats (not bits!). Returns NaN if any of the determinants are zero (because this will make the denominator of the log zero)
Throws:
java.lang.Exception

                                            throws java.lang.Exception

computeSignificance

public ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance()
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception

Compute the statistical significance of the conditional mutual information result analytically, without creating a distribution under the null hypothesis by bootstrapping.

Brillinger (see reference below) shows that under the null hypothesis of no source-destination relationship, the MI for two Gaussian distributions follows a chi-square distribution with degrees of freedom equal to the product of the number of variables in each joint variable.

Specified by:
computeSignificance in interface AnalyticNullDistributionComputer
Returns:
ChiSquareMeasurementDistribution object This object contains the proportion of MI scores from the distribution which have higher or equal MIs to ours.
Throws:
java.lang.Exception
See Also:
Brillinger, "Some data analyses using mutual information", {@link http://www.stat.berkeley.edu/~brill/Papers/MIBJPS.pdf}, et al., "Data Information in Contingency Tables: A Fallacy of Hierarchical Loglinear Models", {@link http://www.jds-online.com/file_download/112/JDS-369.pdf}, and Bossomaier, "Transfer Entropy as a Log-likelihood Ratio" {@link http://arxiv.org/abs/1205.6339}
